review_title: Positive place, but know the hardships of the field.
pros: I love it here. My department, at least, has a positive outlook, friendly and competent coworkers, friendly, open and competent supervisors. I do fun work with a flexible schedule. Working with people with disabilities is incredibly rewarding, and spending time with these people can also be a lot of fun! I've worked for two other companies in this field in the Marion-Polk areas, and RISE is by far the best.
cons:
I don't have any cons for RISE specifically. The cons are problems with the Intellectual Disability/Developmental Disability field in general. ID/DD does not get a lot of funding from the state, so every company in the field pays its floor staff poorly. This is something that is getting better, but it's still something to watch out for. This is a difficult field -- working with ID/DD is very rewarding, but it's also stressful. There is a lot of turnover, which means there are never enough experienced employees. House managers are expected to work insane hours, because there isn't enough money for the state to pay enough to hire enough people.

Side note: No, you are not guaranteed breaks. Whether or not it's "right," Oregon law allows for employers to not give unpaid meal breaks if it would cause "undue hardship" to the employer. Every ID/DD services company I know has a waiver stating that letting caregivers leave for an unpaid break would be harmful to the people under care, and thus "undue hardship." Now, I'm not a lawyer, so this might be inaccurate, but it's what I've been told repeatedly over the years working in the field.

My main point is -- yes, some of what happens at RISE, especially at the low levels, sucks. But it's not RISE specifically, it's the field as a whole. If the reward of the work is worth it to you, then RISE will be a great employer. If it's not, then it won't be.

pros: The people that Rise helps are wonderful and need all the support that they can get. Working with the disabled ether physically or mentally is always a needed profession. As they need to be treated with as much respect as anyone else.

The upper management isn't as supportive or helpful as you would think they would be. 
From not explaining common job practices that you would expect from employers, like the state employee break laws that they over look. To what they call a 24 hour care home. The expectations were unclear from the get go.
Day one of job shadowing, I was scolded after I was told I could go and get my lunch for leaving the house. And it wasn't done quietly, but it was done outside of the residential home as well as it continued in front of the clients of the home. Then I received a sharp email the next day explaining the same thing. 
After researching to see if I was in the wrong or I had done something wrong I found out that this practice is illegal in Oregon. As per state laws you are required to have a 30 minute break from the job if you work 6 or more hours. And if you work 4 or more hours you are to have a 10 break in there as well.
So for an eight hour shift it would be two 10's and a 30 minute break for each shift. But they seem to think they are above this law. 
Sadly, I will not not recommend this job to anyone in the future.
